channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Abigail Spanberger, in Democratic Response, Asks if Trump Is Working for Americans
item.description: “We all know the answer is no,” the Virginia governor argued in her rebuttal to President Trump’s State of the Union address.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein

item.title: Pentagon Gives Anthropic an Ultimatum Over the Company’s A.I. Model
item.description: Anthropic insists on limits on how its technology is used and could be labeled a supply chain risk if it fails to accept the military’s demands.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth summoned the chief executive of Anthropic to Washington for a meeting on Tuesday.

item.title: House Narrowly Rejects Air Safety Bill After Pentagon Opposition
item.description: A move to swiftly pass the bill failed by a single vote. It would have required aircraft to carry technology that officials said might have prevented a midair collision near Washington last year.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.category: Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bill’s failure upends the debate around how to respond to last year’s fatal crash between a military helicopter and a commercial jet over the Potomac River.

item.title: Mexico Is Caught Between Trump and the Cartels
item.description: President Trump has demanded President Claudia Sheinbaum confront the cartels. The killing of El Mencho suggests it might be working — but could come at a cost.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: President Trump and President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico in Washington in December. Mr. Trump has been loudly and repeatedly demanding that Mexican officials dismantle the cartels.

item.title: What to Know About the Cartels Operating in Mexico
item.description: Other criminal groups in Mexico may try to take advantage of the death of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, also known as El Mencho, who ran the Jalisco New Generation Cartel.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Offerings of flowers, candles, photos and dollar bills at a shrine to Jesús Malverde — a “narco-saint,” in Culiacán, Sinaloa state, in 2024.

item.title: Is It Safe to Travel to Mexico Right Now, Given the Cartel Violence?
item.description: A wave of unrest after the killing of a cartel leader has rattled tourists in Mexico, prompting travelers to reconsider their plans. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Shannon Sims
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Americans traveling in Guadalajara, Mexico, were still advised to “shelter in place” as of late Monday.

item.title: Huge Snowball Fight in New York Escalates After Police Arrive
item.description: Police Commissioner Jessica Tisch said officers had been attacked at Washington Square Park. Mayor Zohran Mamdani said the episode looked like a snowball fight, not a crime.
item.dc:creator: Maia Coleman

item.title: Providence, R.I. Digs Out From Three Feet of Snow
item.description: A day after the city got a record-breaking amount of snow, some residents clung to the magic. Others were gearing up for endless shoveling.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Russell and Tom Li
item.media:description: Work crews shovel snow from the steps of the Rhode Island State Capitol on Tuesday in Providence, R.I.

item.title: Blizzard Causes Major Airport Delays and Cancellations: What Travelers Should Know
item.description: As major hubs in the Northeast dig out from up to three feet of snow, it could be days before some travelers get moving. Here’s where things stand.
item.dc:creator: Danial Adkison, Mark Bonamo and Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Travelers at Newark Liberty International Airport on Tuesday, as airlines resumed service after a powerful blizzard disrupted flights.

item.title: Leader of Columbia Brain Institute Quits Over Friendship With Epstein
item.description: The Nobel laureate Richard Axel is not accused of wrongdoing but called his association with Jeffrey Epstein a “serious error in judgment.”
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman
item.media:description: Dr. Richard Axel was a co-director of the Mortimer B. Zuckerman Mind Brain Behavior Institute at Columbia University,

item.title: In Windsor, Some See Family Drama in the Andrew Accusations
item.description: “Her children have let her down,” said one woman, referring to Queen Elizabeth II. Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor’s fall from grace drew strong reactions from some. Others said they just did not care.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Stephen Castle
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II and members of the royal family at Buckingham Palace, in 2019.

item.title: How Jeffrey Epstein Ingratiated Himself With Top Microsoft Executives
item.description: For more than two decades, the convicted sex offender developed a network at the tech giant, making him privy to succession discussions and other business.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith and Karen Weise

item.title: Court Rules Against Justice Dept. Search of Reporter’s Computers
item.description: The judge said the court itself would search the devices, which were seized from a Washington Post reporter’s home last month.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple
item.media:description: The courthouse for the Eastern District of Virginia in Alexandria, where a judge rejected an “unsupervised, wholesale” search by the federal government.

item.title: Kash Patel’s Olympics Trip Left Plenty of Time for Leisure, Schedule Shows
item.description: An itinerary for Mr. Patel’s trip provides more granular detail, including long segments of personal time that suggest he was not immensely oversubscribed by official duties.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.media:description: Kash Patel, the F.B.I. director, watching the United States and Canada in the gold medal hockey game at the Milan Olympics.

item.title: D.O.J. Sues U.C.L.A. After It Refused to Pay $1 Billion Fine
item.description: The Trump administration accused the university’s Los Angeles campus of not doing enough to curb antisemitism, months after the government tried to cut research money and demanded more than $1 billion.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder, Michael C. Bender and Anemona Hartocollis
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: The campus of the University of California, Los Angeles.

item.title: Federal Judiciary Asks Congress to Give Over Control of Courthouses
item.description: In a letter to lawmakers, the courts’ policymaking body claimed that the General Services Administration, part of the executive branch, had been slow to make crucial repairs.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:description: The Everett McKinley Dirksen United States Courthouse in Chicago, where floors were damaged by a water leak in 2024.

item.title: Abu Dhabi’s State Oil Company Looks Beyond Oil
item.description: Having reshaped the company, Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber wants to expand internationally, particularly in natural gas, chemicals and renewables.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed and Natalie Naccache
item.media:description: Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber has helped put ADNOC, Abu Dhabi’s state oil company, on the map as a global deal maker.

item.title: After Being Shoved in Front of a Train, He Has Returned to the Subway
item.description: Joseph Lynskey was determined to overcome his fear and reclaim his life as a New Yorker who enjoys the city in full. On Tuesday, he filed a lawsuit against the city and the M.T.A.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Rosman
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph Lynskey recently returned to the 18th Street subway station in Manhattan, where he had been shoved in front of an oncoming train in 2024.

item.title: Savannah Guthrie Offers $1 Million for Tip Leading to Mother’s Return
item.description: In a new video, the “Today” host acknowledged that her 84-year-old mother may already be dead, but said the family was holding out hope for a miracle.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:description: Nancy Guthrie, right, the mother of the television host Savannah Guthrie, went missing from her home in Tucson, Ariz., on Feb. 1.

item.title: Futsal Phenom in Afghanistan Is a Hero the Taliban Didn’t Expect
item.description: A triumph in indoor soccer has turned Alireza Ahmadi, 17, and other players from the Hazara minority, long marginalized in Afghanistan, into national heroes.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier, Yaqoob Akbary and Tomás Munita
item.media:credit: Tomás Munita for The New York Times

item.title: BAFTAs 2026 Outburst: What Tourette’s Tics Feel Like
item.description: Verbal or physical tics can be a daily struggle. So can dealing with the hurt they may cause.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron and Simar Bajaj
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:description: John Davidson, who has Tourette’s syndrome and is the subject of the biographical film “I Swear,” unintentionally shouted a racist slur while two Black stars were onstage at the BAFTAs.

item.title: John Roberts Is Losing Patience With Trump
item.description: How to read the gratuitous paragraph in the chief justice’s tariff opinion.
item.dc:creator: Linda Greenhouse

item.title: No, the Dollar Is Not Dying
item.description: The currency is stumbling, by many accounts. But the narrative is false.
item.dc:creator: Eswar Prasad

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Goes Live After a Super Long State of the Union
item.description: “I can’t believe America missed an all-new ‘Will Trent’ for this one,” he joked.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Paramount Raises Its Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: Warner Bros. Discovery said Paramount’s new offer of $31 a share could lead to a “superior proposal” to the deal it signed with Netflix.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paramount previously offered $30 a share to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery.

item.title: Judge Dismisses Minnesota Gun Case as Prosecutors Struggle With Resignations
item.description: A judge took the unusual step of dropping the case over a speedy trial violation by the U.S. attorney’s office in Minnesota, which has been flooded with immigration-related cases.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Scott Takushi/Pioneer Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: U.S. District Court Judge Paul Magnuson in his chambers at the Warren E. Burger Federal Building in downtown St. Paul, Minn., in 2021.

item.title: Éliane Radigue, Composer of Time, Silence and Space, Dies at 94
item.description: Her Tibetan Buddhist spiritual practice and her experiments with synthesizers came together in vast, slow-moving works that drew wide acclaim.
item.dc:creator: Peter Catapano
item.media:description: Éliane Radigue in 2011. Her subtly shifting textures seemed to ebb and flow glacially, without the sense of forward motion or drama that has characterized much of Western music.

item.title: Mr. Clean, the Bald, Broad-Shouldered Cleaning Mascot, Retires
item.description: The character became the face of a household cleaner in 1958. It’s not clear what the brand plans for its next mascot.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: Mr. Clean was created in the 1950s, envisioned as a bald man with a nose ring, in a nod to the genie-like powers of the cleaning product.
